title-group.article-title: A review of remote sensing based productivity models and their suitability for studying oil palm productivity in tropical regions

author-notes.corresp: Kasturi Devi Kanniah, Department of Remote Sensing, Faculty of Geoinformation and Real Estate, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, UTM Skudai, 81310 Johor, Malaysia Email: kasturi@utm.my

abstract.p: Oil palm (Elaeis guineensis Jacq.) cultivation has been expanding and has become one of the fastest developing agricultural crops in tropical regions. Therefore, it is critical to understand the carbon balance and dynamics within oil palm estates to determine its role in the global carbon cycle. Estimating oil palm productivity on a large scale is most feasible with remote sensing based models. Thus, the objective of this paper is to review existing remote sensing based models (i.e. CASA, GLO-PEM, VPM, C-Fix, TURC, EC-LUE, VI, TG, 3-PGS and MOD17) that use light use efficiency (LUE) logic, and subsequently to evaluate the suitability of these models for estimating oil palm productivity. This paper also highlights the limitation of current remote sensing based models for estimating oil palm productivity. From the review of existing literature, it is clear that the existing remote sensing based models need to be modified in terms of meteorological inputs, maximum LUE and environmental constraints in order to improve the estimation of oil palm productivity.

sec.title: I Introduction
sec.p: The increase in the global concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) and its involvement in global climate change have led to an urgent need to find the best way to mitigate the emissions of CO2. Photosynthesis by terrestrial vegetation is an important component of the carbon cycle and provides a major sink for atmospheric CO2. Quantifying this sequestration of CO2 is therefore very important in terms of the whole global carbon cycle. One estimate is that photosynthesis from terrestrial vegetation removes about 60 Gt of carbon from the atmosphere every year (Jansen, 2004), though there is a need to refine this figure. Estimating productivity is important because it is one of the fundamental parameters in characterizing the carbon cycle (Ruimy et al., 1999). Additionally, estimating vegetation productivity is critical since it detects how changes in climate influence terrestrial ecosystems and provides insights into possible feedbacks between terrestrial ecosystems’ carbon cycle and future climate change (Nemani et al., 2003; Zhao and Running, 2010).

The productivity of terrestrial ecosystems is concerned with the rate of conversion of atmospheric CO2 into organic compounds, i.e. photosynthesis. Some of the major quantities used for the study of photosynthetic productivity are gross primary productivity (GPP), net primary productivity (NPP) and net ecosystem productivity (NEP) (Hairiah et al., 2001). GPP denotes the total carbon intake by terrestrial ecosystems (g C m−2 year−1) while NPP is the value of GPP less the autotrophic respiration (Ra), in which Ra comprises growth respiration and maintenance respiration by an ecosystem (Chapin et al., 2002; Hairiah et al., 2001). NEP is the value of NPP less the heterotrophic respiration (Rh), i.e. respiration due to the decomposition or decay involving organic matter, microbes, soil organisms, etc. (Hairiah et al., 2001). By definition, these represent the several processes involving the carbon gained by ecosystems through photosynthesis, and carbon lost through respiration, which are vital to assisting us to understand the carbon balance of an ecosystem.

Numerous studies of estimating productivity in tropical regions have been conducted to discover their role in the global carbon cycle. Most of these studies were conducted primarily on forest ecosystems (Gebremichael and Barros, 2006; Hutley et al., 2005; Kanniah et al., 2009; Saleska et al., 2003; Xiao et al., 2004a, 2005a, 2005b). Presently, there is still a lack of research on estimating productivity in other tropical ecosystems, particularly for tree crops (Navarro et al., 2008) such as oil palm (Elaeis guineensis Jacq.). Oil palm occupies over 14.92 Mha of land and produces 210.33 Mt of oil palm fruit globally (FAO, 2009). Oil palm cultivation has been expanding and it is one of the fastest developing agricultural crops in tropical regions (Koh and Wilcove, 2008). Southeast Asia is the largest palm oil producer; it covers 64.02% of the world’s’ total oil palm area and produces 85.36% of the world’s total palm oil (FAO, 2009) (Table 1). Since the use of renewable energy is encouraged in Malaysia, the utilization of oil palm biomass and its wastes is taken seriously and is important to reduce the consumption of non-renewable energy sources such as coal, oil and natural gas. Biofuel, biochar, 1 mulching, furniture, fertilizer, etc. produced from oil palm biomass and its wastes have successfully contributed to the sustainable use of energy while reducing the negative impact of oil palm cultivation on the environment (Sulaiman et al., 2011).

sec.p: In terms of the economy, estimating oil palm productivity such as NEP could provide an opportunity to relate the carbon sequestered by oil palms with the carbon credit. The carbon credit could be tradable to produce income in the international emission trading (IET) scheme which has been promoted by the Kyoto Protocol (Germer and Sauerborn, 2008; Oh and Chua, 2010). Yet currently this is seldom being practised in the oil palm industry. In addition, estimating oil palm productivity is useful for oil palm industries such as Wilmar International, Golden Agri-Resources Limited, Presco Public Limited, IOI Group, Sime Darby Group and the Malaysian Federal Land Development Authority Holdings (FELDA), because it has the potential to provide valuable information for precision farming (i.e. identification and monitoring of lower yield regions), resulting in better land management practice. This is particularly vital to Malaysia, where oil palm is the largest commercial agricultural crop in the country. Identification of lower productivity areas of oil palm could assist the companies with lower profit per hectare, such as FELDA holdings and Sime Darby Group (Table 2), to remedy those areas of low yield regions.

sec.p: Since the demand for palm oil and therefore its economical value are promising, the area devoted to oil palm plantations globally is increasing. There has, therefore, been considerable interest in conducting a quantitative study to understand the carbon balance and dynamics within oil palm estates. From previous studies we see that the carbon pool of oil palm is disputed. Comparison of the physiological parameters of oil palm, tropical rainforest and tropical forest were reported by Lamade and Bouillet (2005) and the Malaysia Palm Oil Council (MPOC, 2007). They argued that oil palm plantations sequester more CO2 than tropical forest because of better physiological capabilities of oil palm in photosynthetic efficiency, radiation conversion efficiency, net CO2 assimilation and biomass production than forest ecosystems (Table 3). However, it is not enough to consider the annual rate of sequestration of carbon, taking NPP for example, by an oil palm estate during its years of production as a mature estate. One needs to consider the whole cycle, starting with what was on the land before the land was prepared for the oil palms, whether it was tropical rain forest or whether it was a region of very low carbon sequestration such as grassland or abandoned land, and at the other end consider what happens to an oil palm plantation when its useful life is finished. Recently, Henson (2008) justified the carbon balance of oil palm by evaluating the carbon emission or sequestration during oil palm cultivation, land-cover change, transportation and manufacturing. The findings revealed that a massive amount of CO2 is emitted from the soil when it is disturbed during the establishment (i.e. deforestation, open-burning, land use change, etc.), by fertilizing the land, transportation and manufacturing and it may take more than a hundred years to compensate for the carbon that has been emitted to the atmosphere during these processes (Henson, 2008). However, instead of comparison with tropical rain forest, oil palms could also act as a carbon sink when oil palm plantations replace regions of ineffective CO2 sequestration such as grasslands and abandoned lands (Germer and Sauerborn, 2008). As already mentioned, it is important to consider the whole cycle of the lifetime of an oil palm estate. In the first few years, after the preparation of the land, when the young plants have been transplanted from the nursery the NPP is very low. It is also important to take into account what happens to the fronds when they have fallen to the ground. Are they collected and burned, releasing CO2, or are they left on the ground to rot? At the end of the useful life of the palms, what happens to them? Are they used in construction programmes or for making furniture, in which case the CO2 remains fixed, or are they burned, thereby releasing their carbon as CO2? We just mention these points to illustrate that a simple calculation of the relative productivity of an area of tropical forest and of a mature oil palm estate, as in Table 3, does not tell the full story.

sec.p: While estimating oil palm productivity is obviously of economic importance, it is also potentially capable of assessing the role of oil palm plantations as a sink or source of carbon dioxide. However, at present, studies are insufficient to quantify the spatial and temporal variation in patterns of oil palm productivity. There is an urgent need to conduct quantitative and comprehensive studies to elucidate the spatial and temporal patterns of oil palm productivity in order to assess its role in the carbon cycle and climate change. There are various techniques available to measure oil palm productivity ranging from plot-based to remote sensing techniques that cover large spatial and long temporal scales. These techniques are briefly described in the following section.

sec.title: II Methods of estimating oil palm productivity
sec.p: Oil palm productivity at small scale can be estimated using techniques such as biometric observations and Eddy Covariance based flux towers. Biometric measurement at plot scale involves estimating the biomass of oil palm which comprises the weight of aboveground (i.e. trunk, frond, leaf, fruit and litter of oil palm) and belowground (i.e. roots), when placed in an oven and dried at 60°C. The weight of the remains after drying is measured to determine the carbon content of an oil palm (Syahrinudin, 2005). Even though the result of this method is direct and reliable, it is destructive and could be costly if it includes multiple samples. This just gives the biomass of the tree at one stage in its lifetime. To find the rate of increase of the biomass one would need to use a number of similar trees of different ages.

Generally, an allometric equation is often used in forestry to relate the measurable parameters of plants (such as age, diameter at breast height, tree height) to carbon stocks (Ketterings et al., 2001). An allometric equation is developed based on a strong statistical relationship between the carbon stocks obtained from plot-based measurement of certain parameters. In oil palm, parameters such as age and trunk height are applied in an allometric equation for determining carbon stocks (Khalid et al., 1999; Syahrinudin, 2005; Thenkabail et al., 2004). However, an allometric equation developed for oil palm is site dependent in terms of the local weather, and density of oil palm per hectare; therefore an allometric equation should be used with caution in different regions. Ideally one would like to have biometric data for the development of an allometric equation. However, while measurements of the above-ground part of the tree can be done non-destructively, accurate below-ground observations like root measurements of an oil palm are difficult to obtain non-destructively. When dealing with a mixture of species or a larger scale or regional scale, estimating productivity using this method is impractical and this leads to the popularity of Eddy Covariance flux towers.

The use of an Eddy Covariance based flux tower is a non-destructive approach which utilizes a real-time measurement that involves a set of automated instruments using Eddy Covariance techniques (Baldocchi et al., 1996). A flux tower is suitable for high temporal and long-term observations, to describe the sink or source patterns of oil palm productivity (Henson, 1993). With micrometeorological instruments employed on the flux tower, the CO2 exchange at the oil palm-atmosphere interface can be estimated. In-situ instruments, such as the sonic anemometer and the infrared gas analyser, are employed on the flux tower to measure the micrometeorological variables such as three-dimensional wind speed, horizontal wind speed, CO2 concentration, net radiation, air temperature, relative humidity, rainfall, canopy surface temperature, solar radiation and photosynthetically active radiation (Table 4). This method has been used for oil palm because of its relatively easy operation and with increasingly advanced instruments that could provide a more accurate estimation (Henson, 1993; Henson and Harun, 2005).

The atmosphere contains turbulent motions of air or eddies that are moving vertically and are carrying CO2. Eddies that develop at the ground surface, within the canopy as well as above the oil palm canopy are responsible for the net ecosystem exchange (NEE) of CO2 between the oil palm-atmosphere interfaces (Figure 1). The Eddy Covariance technique measures the NEE using the Reynolds decomposition (Baldocchi, 2003; Reynolds, 1895). The NEE or eddy flux over a timespan, F, is defined as: Figure 1.

This is the product of the mean air density (ρa) and the mean value of the product of the vertical velocity (w′) and the mixing ratio of CO2 (s’). The overbar denotes the mean of the variables over a timespan. A positive sign of F indicates the CO2 flux outflow to the atmosphere, while a negative sign indicates that the CO2 flux is from the atmosphere to the plant. A flux tower can be used to estimate the GPP of an approximately 1 km2 footprint by the summation of NEE less respiration, i.e. GPP=Σ(NEE–respiration), whereas NPP can be estimated directly by subtracting the Ra from GPP (Turner et al., 2003). Respiration is estimated at night when the CO2 concentration by respiration is dominant and the values during the day are adjusted as a function of air temperature (Henson, 1993).

A previous study using an Eddy Covariance based flux tower for oil palm by Henson and Harun (2005) expressed the view that to estimate fluxes at night accurately using covariance techniques is complex. Furthermore, it is expensive in terms of the advanced instruments, maintenance and manpower requirement. For oil palm ecosystems, estimation of oil palm productivity remains a challenging task due to the lack of a flux tower network. When there are reasons causing field observations to be absent, one should consider modelling for estimating oil palm productivity.

The collecting of large amounts of field data may be impractical for financial reasons. Therefore, models are helpful in simulating oil palm productivity with a variety of spatial and temporal resolutions. They are also useful in evaluating ecosystem responses to environmental changes (Govindasamy et al., 2005). An oil palm productivity model, namely the SIMPALM model, has given a brief picture about the carbon sequestration of oil palm in Southeast Asia and Africa in association with a simple relationship between photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) and leaf area index (LAI) (Lamade and Bouillet, 2005; Lamade and Setiyo, 1996). The CO2 intakes by oil palm in Southeast Asia and Africa were estimated to be 1.03 kg C yr−1 m−2 and 0.95 kg C yr−1 m−2, respectively (Lamade and Bouillet, 2005).

The Oil Palm Simulator (OPSIM), which is an oil palm productivity model that follows the model structure developed by van Kraalingen et al. (1989), has also been used to estimate CO2 intake by oil palm in Malaysia (Henson, 2000). The model gives a reliable CO2 estimation in accordance with comprehensive factors that affect oil palm productivity, including parameters such as PAR, vapour pressure deficit (VPD), temperature, soil water deficit (SWD) and physiological parameters of oil palm like LAI, light extinction coefficient and light-saturation of photosynthesis to elucidate oil palm productivity. However, the model is suggested to decrease the reliance on the level of empiricism (Henson, 2000).

The advantages and disadvantages of these various methods are summarized in Figure 2. The common question of the above techniques is whether they are suitable to represent all the oil palm ecosystems at regional or larger scale. Since quantitative studies of oil palm productivity at regional scale are limited, studies using remote sensing techniques are vital because it is the most feasible tool to estimate the oil palm productivity at adequate spatial and temporal resolutions. Furthermore, various remote sensing based productivity models have shown promising results in estimating the productivity of various biomes in the world but it is necessary to determine the suitability of existing models for oil palm study. For these reasons, this paper reviews remote sensing based models and their suitability for studying oil palm productivity in tropical regions (sections III and IV), to find out the limitations of current remote sensing based productivity models and to propose approaches to modify a specific remote sensing based productivity model for estimating oil palm productivity (sections V and VI).

sec.title: III Remote sensing based productivity estimation
sec.p:
Remote sensing is defined as an art, science or technology that involves acquiring information pertinent to the Earth without coming into physical contact with the objects on the Earth (Lillesand et al., 2004). CO2 intake by ecosystems can be inferred from remote sensing based productivity models. A remote sensing based productivity model that utilizes light use efficiency (LUE) logic is used to estimate ecosystem productivity as a function of the maximum efficiency of photosynthesis, absorbed active solar radiation for photosynthesis and environmental factors that constrain photosynthesis (Hilker et al., 2008b; McCallum et al., 2009). The use of LUE was initiated by Monteith (1972), and later formed the basis for using remote sensing in quantifying plant primary productivity (GPP and NPP). Monteith (1972) found that crop productivity was linearly related to the absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (APAR) of crops, which also implicitly displayed the amount of leaf area in the vegetation. APAR was then converted into final tissue growth (productivity) by a conversion efficiency term (LUE) of plants. LUE is based on two fundamental assumptions that (1) ecosystem productivity is directly related to APAR and (2) maximum LUE is constrained by environmental factors such as vapour pressure deficit (VPD), temperature and soil water shortages The LUE equations are as follows: 2
GPP=APAR×(maximumLUE×environmental constraints scalars)

and 3
fPAR=APAR/PAR

Equation 3 can be rearranged as follows: 4
APAR=fPAR×PAR

Gross primary productivity (GPP) involves absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (APAR), maximum light use efficiency (maximum LUE) of an ecosystem and environmental constraints (i.e. soil water stress, temperature, vapour pressure deficit, etc.) as scaling factors (i.e. their values vary from 0 to 1, where 0 and 1 indicate full suppression and no suppression respectively) to scale down the maximum LUE. fPAR is the fraction of photosynthetically active radiation that is actually absorbed by vegetation and it is an important variable in estimating canopy productivity, evapotranspiration and energy balance (Turner et al., 1999). PAR is the solar radiation (0.4–0.7 µm) reaching the canopy for photosynthesis (McCallum et al., 2009). Kumar and Monteith (1982) proposed an empirical relation in which fPAR can be linearly related to the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): 5
fPAR=a×NDVI+b

where a and b are constants which are site-specific as well as depending on many other factors such as forest stand age, species composition, soil fertility, foliar nutrients, drought, radiation, phenological stage, climatic condition and temperature (McCallum et al., 2009). NDVI is a ratio (i.e. (near infrared – red)/(near infrared + red)) using the reflectance of the near infrared channel (0.7 to 1.3 μm) and the red channel (0.4 to 0.5 μm) (Lillesand et al., 2004). The sharp contrast in reflectivity in these spectral bands due to the optical properties of chlorophyll and the internal structure of green leaf cells makes NDVI a very useful measure in vegetation studies (Zhao and Running, 2008). The direct relationship between NDVI and observed ecosystem productivity was first demonstrated by Goward et al. (1985) using a linear relationship over different vegetation types in North America. Annual NPP at the global scale was first studied by Fung et al. (1987) based on NDVI, without incorporating any environmental factors such as temperature and moisture that can constrain maximum productivity.

Recently, the use of vegetation indices to estimate fPAR has been increasing. Other than the NDVI, the Enhanced Vegetation index (EVI) has been used in a variety of forest ecosystems and also crop ecosystems (e.g. maize, wheat) (Gitelson et al., 2008; Wu et al., 2010a, 2010c). The EVI includes a blue band for atmospheric correction (Xiao et al., 2005b) and is found to be less sensitive to aerosol effects compared to the NDVI. Consequently, the EVI has become more popular to estimate fPAR in remote sensing based productivity models such as the Vegetation Photosynthesis Model (VPM), Temperature and Greenness model (TG) and Vegetation Index model (VI).

Most of the existing LUE models use vegetation indices (i.e. NDVI, EVI) to estimate fPAR empirically (as is discussed in the following section). Although these relationships were commonly used, however, recent studies have shown that this assumption does not apply in all regions (Gitelson et al., 2008). Vegetation indices are more suitable to define the healthiness/abundance of vegetation rather than to quantify biophysical parameters like fPAR. Besides, a vegetation index like NDVI is influenced by atmospheric conditions and soil background (Xiao et al., 2003). The sensitivity of NDVI to detect fPAR reaches saturation when fPAR goes beyond 70% (Viña and Gitelson, 2005). Furthermore, converting satellite spectral reflectance to fPAR over larger areas is difficult because the measurement of NDVI is site specific rather than region specific (Hilker et al., 2008b). Unlike the empirical approach, Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) primary productivity product MOD17 calculates fPAR for different biome types over the globe utilizing a robust three-dimensional algorithm, which is based on radiative transfer theory (Knyazikhin et al., 1999) (see MOD17 in section V).

sec.title: IV Suitability of existing remote sensing based models for oil palm productivity studies
sec.p: In this section we review nine remote sensing based models which utilize LUE logic as follows:

Eddy Covariance Light Use Efficiency Model (EC-LUE)

sec.p: All of these models involve various different vegetation indices and various different attempts to relate these vegetation indices to plant productivity. The various vegetation indices have all been introduced as empirical quantities; there has been no attempt to relate them to the actual biophysics of the process of photosynthesis and all these models should therefore be regarded as empirical models. The models are reviewed in accordance with their potential to address the spatial and temporal dynamics for estimating oil palm productivity. The models are briefly discussed below and components of these models are shown in Table 5.

sec.title: 1 Carnegie Ames Standford Approach Model (CASA)
sec.p: Potter et al. (1993) combined AVHRR satellite data (NDVI), monthly temperature, precipitation, soil attributes and a biome-independent potential maximum LUE at a constant rate (0.389 g C m−2 MJ−1) to estimate monthly global terrestrial NPP. This model has a spatial resolution of 0.5° and estimates NPP directly, without estimating GPP and autotrophic respiration (Ra) separately. Environmental constraints such as temperature and soil moisture are used to scale down the maximum LUE. The results from CASA were well correlated with the NPP of ground measurements in a regional scale such as the Indian continent, but when compared with a single biome such as croplands, forest and grasslands CASA showed lower agreement (Nayak et al., 2009). This is mainly because the maximum LUE (0.389 g C m−2 MJ−1) of CASA is not comparable with the maximum LUE of various biomes. Therefore, CASA is designed for use with global biomes rather than for use with a single biome. This problem could be resolved by incorporating a land-cover map and using the maximum LUE of each biome instead of the constant value used by CASA (Yu et al., 2009).

sec.title: 2 Global Production Efficiency Model (GLO-PEM)
sec.p: Prince and Goward (1995) estimated global GPP and NPP using NOAA AVHRR data at 8 km spatial resolution and 10 days temporal resolution by relating satellite derived NDVI to field measurements of fPAR by a linear function. This model calculates GPP and Ra independently and subtracts Ra from GPP to obtain NPP. GLO-PEM was the first model to estimate global productivity completely from remotely sensed meteorological inputs and biophysical variables (Prince and Goward, 1995). This model utilizes two different maximum values of LUE for C3 and C4 plants which have different photosynthetic pathways. For C3 plants the maximum LUE adopted by GLO-PEM is 55.2α g C m-2 MJ-1 where α is the invariant quantum yield of photosynthesis (Prince and Goward, 1995). C3 plants are those that use Ribulose-1.5-bisphosphate carboxylase oyggenase or RuBisCo to fix CO2 and produce 3−phosphoglycerate, which is a 3-carbon compound; examples of C3 plants include wheat and potatoes (Furbank and Taylor, 1995). For C4 plants this model uses 2.76 g C m−2 MJ−1 as the maximum LUE; C4 plants are those that use phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase (also known as PEP carboxylase, PEPCase, or PEPC) to form the four-carbon compound oxaloacetate to fix CO2; maize is an example of a C4 plant (Furbank and Taylor, 1995). Environmental constraints such as temperature, VPD and soil moisture are used to scale the maximum LUE of GLO-PEM. Oil palm is a C3 plant, but the discrepancy between the maximum LUE of GLO-PEM for C3 plants (55.2α g C m−2 MJ−1) and oil palm (1.6 g C m−2 MJ−1) (MPOC, 2007; Md Noor and Harun, 2004) is enormous. This can cause significant errors due to the much lower maximum LUE value estimated for oil palm.

sec.title: 3 Terrestrial Vegetation Photosynthesis Model (VPM)
sec.p: The VPM was developed by Xiao et al. (2004a, 2004b, 2005a, 2005b) to estimate GPP from the MODIS and SPOT VEGETATION sensors. They used the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) to account for PAR absorbed by green leaves and functions of optimum temperature, water and leaf phenology to scale down the maximum LUE. Soil water condition is represented using a land surface water index (LSWI) that is calculated from the near infrared and shortwave infrared spectral bands. This model has been tested in different ecosystems such as evergreen needle leaf forest (Xiao et al., 2004a, 2005a, 2005b), temperate deciduous broad leaf forest (Xiao et al., 2004b) and seasonally moist tropical evergreen forest (Xiao et al., 2005a). In tropical evergreen forest, old-growth trees develop deep roots to absorb underground water during the dry season, and leaf phenology of tropical forests that usually remains a dense canopy makes it hard for VPM to estimate the seasonal variation accurately (Xiao et al., 2005a). Hence, the future development of LUE models for tropical regions should take account of these two aspects.

sec.title: 4 Parametric Production Efficiency Model (C-Fix)
sec.p:
C-Fix estimates ecosystem productivity ranging from local to global scale by using three inputs, namely solar radiation, temperature and APAR (Veroustraete et al., 2002, 2004). Unlike the other models that only estimate GPP and/or NPP, this model provides NPP by GPP less Ra (Goward and Dye, 1987; Verstraeten et al., 2006) and NEP by NPP less Rh (Veroustraete et al., 2004). The maximum LUE of C-Fix is set to a constant of 1.10 g C m−2 MJ−1 and it is reduced by temperature, soil moisture, evaporative fraction, respiration (i.e. Ra and Rh) and CO2 fertilization scaling factors. Further modifications of C-Fix, namely converting atmospheric temperature to biome and soil temperature as well as incorporating a water limitation function, were introduced by Verstraeten et al. (2006) to estimate NEP, and this has improved the correlation of the model with site observations (R
2 = 0.63).

sec.title: 5 Uptake and Release of Carbon Model (TURC)
sec.p: Initially, TURC was used to estimate GPP which was then used to estimate NPP by subtracting Ra from GPP (Ruimy et al., 1999). The maximum LUE of TURC is set as 1.10 g C m−2 MJ-1. TURC was chosen by Sharma (2009) in an oil palm carbon study. The carbon stock of oil palm in Riau, Indonesia, was estimated and it was found to overestimate (60 tonnes per ha) the carbon stock mainly in the mature oil palm. Besides, the findings showed that environmental constraints such as soil water deficit (SWD) are crucial to be included in the model to estimate oil palm productivity accurately during drought or in drier regions.

sec.title: 6 Eddy Covariance Light Use Efficiency Model (EC-LUE)
sec.p:
Yuan et al. (2007) developed a remote sensing based productivity model driven by NDVI that is assumed to be linearly correlated with fPAR, temperature, PAR and evaporative fraction (the Bowen ratio of sensible to latent heat flux). This model relies on Eddy Covariance based flux towers as major input and remotely sensed NDVI from MODIS. The maximum LUE of EC-LUE uses a constant value of 2.14 g C m−2 MJ−1. The Bowen ratio of sensible to latent heat flux measured from a climate observations network is used to estimate the water availability of soil and vegetation. Environmental constraints like soil temperature and soil moisture are used to scale the maximum LUE of an ecosystem. The EC-LUE is capable of capturing the spatial and temporal dynamics of various ecosystems’ productivity because the parameters of the model (i.e. potential light use efficiency and optimal plant growth temperature) are different in different ecosystems. However, the accuracy of EC-LUE is relatively low for large regions because of the poor performance of the Bowen ratio (Yuan et al., 2007). Further modifications of EC-LUE by replacing the Bowen ratio with the ratio of evapotranspiration to net radiation has improved the accuracy (R
2 = 0.61) when the model was validated with site observations (Yuan et al., 2010).

sec.title: 7 Vegetation Index Model (VI)
sec.p:
The VI model estimates GPP based on remotely sensed vegetation indices. Various vegetation indices – for instance, EVI, NDVI, Weight Difference Vegetation Index (WDVI) and Soil-Adjusted Vegetation Index (SAVI) – were investigated for their capability to represent fPAR and LUE (Wu et al., 2010c). EVI shows the highest correlation for both fPAR (R
2 = 0.76) and LUE (R
2 = 0.87) whereas NDVI and SAVI show the lowest correlation for LUE (R
2 = 0.63) and fPAR (R
2 = 0.69), respectively. GPP is estimated from meteorologically estimated PAR and two vegetation indices (i.e. PAR × Vegetation index × Vegetation index) where the vegetation indices are surrogates for fPAR and LUE (Wu et al., 2010c). Among the vegetation indices, results showed that PAR × EVI × EVI agreed best with GPP in croplands such as maize (R
2 = 0.91) (Wu et al., 2010c) and wheat (R
2 = 0.92) (Wu et al., 2010a) as well as in deciduous forest (R
2 = 0.90) (Wu et al., 2010b). Their findings have extended the potential use of the vegetation indices in remote sensing based productivity models to estimate ecosystem productivity.

sec.title: 8 Temperature and Greenness Model (TG)
sec.p:
The TG model uses simple relationships entirely based on MODIS land surface temperature (LST) and MODIS EVI (Sims et al., 2008). Unlike the other LUE models, this model does not use PAR as input. It uses LST instead of PAR because Sims et al. (2008) found that there are strong relationships between LST and both PAR and VPD in North America. GPP is then estimated as a product of scaled LST and scaled EVI. Among the various models, the TG is less complex as it uses fewer variables (i.e. LST and EVI); therefore the model is proposed to be used to estimate ecosystem productivity when there is no prior knowledge about the site (Wu et al., 2010b). Generally, the TG model agreed well (R
2 = 0.79–0.94) with nine site measurements in North America (Sims et al., 2008).

sec.title: 9 3-Physiological Principles Predicting Growth using Satellites (3-PGS)
sec.p:
The 3-PGS model developed by Coops et al. (1998) uses a constant maximum LUE (1.8 g C m−2 MJ−1) and inputs of meteorological data (e.g. solar radiation, PAR, temperature, VPD, rainfall and frost), soil information (e.g. fertility and soil moisture) and biophysical parameters (e.g. fPAR and physiological information) to estimate vegetation productivity. A previous study demonstrated that above ground NPP estimated by the 3-PGS shows high correlation (R
2 = 0.82) with measured wood production (Coops et al., 1998). Furthermore, comparisons of the model with the MOD17 demonstrate high agreement (within 20%) in estimating forest GPP in the USA (Nightingale et al., 2007). Also, comparison with a process-based physiological model, namely BIOME-BGC, has also shown high correlation (R
2 = 0.85) in estimating forest NPP in the Siskiyou Mountains, southwestern Oregon (Coops et al., 2001). Recently, Waring et al. (2010) reviewed the use of radar, lidar, multispectral and hyperspectral remote sensing and have suggested that remote sensing would improve the model by estimating the seasonal variation of canopy photosynthetic capacity (a function of fPAR, nitrogen, chlorophyll content) and canopy conductance (a function of VPD and soil moisture).

sec.title: V Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer primary productivity products (MOD17)
sec.p: Unlike all the other models we have just mentioned, the product MOD17 does not rely on empirically defined vegetation indices, but attempts to model the biochemical and physical processes involved in photosynthesis. The MOD17 is operational at a global scale utilizing a modified version of the LUE algorithms and three upstream inputs, MODIS land-cover products (MOD12), LAI/fPAR (MOD15), and daily meteorological data from the Global Modeling and Assimilation Office (GMAO) (Heinsch et al., 2003; Zhao et al., 2005) to estimate global GPP.

MODIS utilizes a modified version of the LUE algorithm of Monteith (1972) to estimate GPP as described below: 6
MODISGPP = Maximum LUE × T
MIN
(0-1) × VPD (0-1) × APAR
7
APAR=fPAR×PAR

Fractional photosynthetic active radiation (fPAR) data is obtained from MOD15. Daily climate data (shortwave radiation, VPD and Tmin) used in GPP estimations are provided by the GMAO. Photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) is equal to shortwave radiation (SWrad) multiplied by 0.45 (Heinsch et al., 2003). The MOD17 algorithm utilizes a MODIS Biome Properties Look-Up Table (BPLUT) for 11 different biomes computed using BIOME-BGC, which is a process-based ecosystem model. The BPLUT contains parameters such as maximum LUE, the limits of VPD and temperature, and vegetation respiration for each biome. The maximum LUE is further scaled down by environmental constraints (i.e. daily average minimum temperature (TMIN) under dry conditions and daytime average vapour pressure deficit (VPD) under cold conditions) as scaling factors, 0–1 (Heinsch et al., 2003).

Maintenance respiration by roots and leaves is computed based on an exponential function of average daily temperature and scaled down by leaf mass, which is a ratio of LAI to specific leaf area (SLA) (Heinsch et al., 2003). MODIS produces 8-day summation GPP and daily PSNnet (GPP less roots and leaves maintenance respiration) as illustrated in Figures 3a and 3b, respectively. The MODIS annual NPP is computed by aggregation of the daily PSNnet to annual PSNnet, followed by subtracting live wood maintenance respiration and growth respiration (e.g. live wood, dead wood, root and leaf) (Figure 3c).

caption.p: MODIS approach to derive annual NPP

sec.p: MODIS LAI/fPAR (MOD15) is estimated using a physically based radiative transfer model. In this model, a Look Up Table (LUT) is utilized. The observed reflectances are measured for a range of conditions and stored in the LUT (Knyazikhin et al., 1999). Furthermore, MODIS LAI/fPAR compares the observed reflectances with modelled reflectances by taking into account the bidirectional reflectances from various canopy structures, under-canopy structures, soil, etc. If the difference between the modelled and observed reflectances is within the uncertainty (20%) of the observed reflectance, the mean values of LAI and fPAR are returned from the LUT (Knyazikhin et al., 1999). If the uncertainty of the modelled and observed reflectances lies beyond the acceptable uncertainty due to poor atmospheric conditions such as cloud contamination and aerosol, MODIS estimates LAI/fPAR using a back-up algorithm, which is an empirical relationship using NDVI (Knyazikhin et al., 1999). Thus, the quality of a remotely sensed pixel by MODIS to determine the LAI/fPAR is either estimated from a radiative transfer model or an empirical function. MODIS products’ quality assurance that is being produced operationally is important to determine the quality of MODIS pixels (Heinsch et al., 2003; Turner et al., 2003).

A recent study to evaluate the performance of MODIS 8-day gross primary productivity product (MOD17A2) of tropical oil palm in Malaysia has shown that the model underestimated the site GPP by 19–29% (Tan et al., 2011). The underestimates are because of the poor representation of LAI and fPAR (i.e. underestimation 10–16.79% and 9.66–10.80% respectively) due to massive cloud contamination in tropical regions, low correlation between in-situ meteorological data and the MOD17 meteorological data, ranging from R
2 = 0.02 (PAR) to R
2 = 0.26 (daily minimum temperature) and 60% misclassification which occurred in MOD12. According to the principal investigator of MODIS land cover (Mark Friedl, personal communication, 12 December 2011), MODIS cannot distinguish between forest and plantations and therefore oil palm trees with relatively high LAI (about 4) are classified as evergreen forest (Tan et al., 2011). These introduce uncertainties to the MOD17 estimates. Besides, the MOD17 algorithm does not include soil water in the consideration (Heinsch et al., 2006) and this may cause the underestimates. Coops et al. (2007) and Yuan et al. (2007) modified the MOD17 algorithm by including antecedent rainfall, potential evaporation and evaporative fraction as surrogates for soil water availability and this has improved the GPP estimation. Moreover, Kanniah et al. (2009) utilized a moisture index to replace the VPD scalar in tropical savanna ecosystems, and this has also successfully improved the estimation of GPP in tropical savannas. These studies reported that the inclusion of soil water availability as an environmental constraint is crucial to be included in the MOD17 algorithm to estimate ecosystem productivity.

sec.title: VI Limitations of remote sensing based productivity models for estimating oil palm productivity in tropical regions
sec.p: This section highlights the limitations of current remote sensing based productivity models in estimating oil palm productivity, and suggests potential developments to the remote sensing based productivity model for oil palm.

sec.title: 1 Meteorological inputs and biophysical variables
sec.p: The accuracy of the remote sensing based productivity models that utilize LUE is extremely reliant on the quality of the inputs such as meteorological inputs (i.e. PAR, temperature and VPD, etc.). Various studies around the world have evaluated the existing climate data sets and the results showed that the variation caused by the data sets with site observation are 16–43% (Ito and Sasai, 2006), 27% (± 45%) (Zhao et al., 2005), 18–77% (Gebremichael and Barros, 2006) and 28% (Heinsch et al., 2006), respectively, and the major uncertainty occurs in estimating VPD (Heinsch et al., 2006). In addition, tropical regions showed the largest discrepancy compared to other latitudes (Ito and Sasai, 2006; Zhao et al., 2006).

The low quality of meteorological inputs is always a problem where tropical regions are contaminated by clouds and pollutants most of the time (Zhao et al., 2005). Massive clouds and pollutants are dynamic and they could influence the meteorological input as well as remotely sensed quantities such as fPAR and LAI. An attempt has been made in the MOD17 product to solve the cloud coverage problem which causes poor representation of pixel values. In the MOD17 product, quality assurances are being produced operationally to determine the quality of MODIS pixels (Heinsch et al., 2003; Turner et al., 2003). Low quality of fPAR and LAI caused by cloud contamination, sensor failure, etc., is remedied by temporal filling with data from the nearest date of non cloud-contaminated fPAR/LAI (Zhao et al., 2005).

Also, poor results in tropical regions could be due to lack of ground meteorological stations to use in the existing meteorological reanalysis data sets since the models rely on the existing ground meteorological observations network derived data sets (e.g. GMAO) as meteorological inputs (McCallum et al., 2009; Zhao et al., 2006). Therefore, it is urgent to increase the number of ground meteorological stations in tropical regions. Despite this, a prominent estimation of ecosystem productivity which utilizes local meteorological data from Eddy Covariance based flux towers can significantly improve the GPP estimation (Heinsch et al., 2006; Kanniah et al., 2009).

Generally, meteorological data are provided at coarse resolution (1° × 1° or approximately 100 km spatial resolution). At local scale, errors appear in meteorological reanalysis data sets where very coarse spatial resolution has generalized the topographical disparity and ignores the orographic effects in mountain areas within the pixels (Zhao et al., 2005). For that reason, non-linear spatial interpolation of four adjacent very coarse resolutions is interpolated to downscale to 1 km, which is compatible with the MODIS pixel size (Zhao et al., 2005). It was found that these techniques have successfully improved the accuracy of estimating productivity when compared to ground data (Zhao et al., 2005).

By contrast with the fact that cloud cover and pollutants are limiting productivity, it was found that solar radiation diffused by clouds and aerosols is able to increase the LUE of oil palms (Henson, 2000). LUE is higher in cloudy and high aerosol regions because of better distribution of diffused solar radiation and better light penetration to the shaded canopy of the oil palms. Furthermore, the diffuse radiation has resulted in greater CO2 intake in shaded leaves as compared with sunlit leaves in a deciduous forest area (Law et al., 2002). Therefore, it is suggested that solar radiation should be separated into cloud-free (direct solar radiation) and cloudy (diffuse solar radiation) which can be determined by a clearness index (i.e. a ratio of global solar radiation received at the surface to the extraterrestrial solar radiation) and the solar elevation angle (Law et al., 2002) in the development of the future remote sensing based productivity models. This is critical in tropical regions because the regions are commonly contaminated by massive clouds.

sec.title: 2 Constant value of maximum LUE to represent oil palm ecosystem
sec.p: Remote sensing based models that use a constant value of maximum LUE (i.e. CASA, GLO-PEM, VPM, C-Fix, TURC, EC-LUE, 3-PGS and MOD17) are scaled down by environmental constraints to estimate ecosystem productivity. Studies have claimed that maximum LUE should not be assumed as a constant value because it varies depending on local soil conditions, meteorological conditions, heterogeneity of species, physiology, age, maintenance respiration, etc. (McCallum et al., 2009). Even in a given species, maximum LUE varies with age. Therefore, the assumption of claiming maximum LUE as a constant is not valid (McCallum et al., 2009).

The models CASA, C-Fix, TURC, EC-LUE and 3-PGS use a constant value of maximum LUE for multiple biomes at regional scale. These models are designed to estimate multiple biomes rather than a single biome like oil palm. Thus, use of these models to estimate oil palm productivity may induce errors in the estimation. The MOD17 developed 11 biomes and one of the biomes is croplands, but the maximum LUE of the MOD17 croplands (1.21 g C m−2 MJ−1) (Zhao, personal communication, 2010) is lower than the maximum LUE of oil palm (1.6 g C m−2 MJ−1) (MPOC, 2007; Md Noor and Harun, 2004). The MOD17 croplands maximum LUE was obtained from the calibration of maize and soybean (Heinsch et al., 2003), hence caution should be applied when using the MOD17 croplands to represent other crops such as oil palm.

In view of the difficulties that occur when using a constant value for maximum LUE, consequently the use of the Photochemical Reflectance Index (PRI) has become popular to be a surrogate of LUE. PRI is a ratio of (reflectance at 0.531µm – reflectance at 0.570 µm)/(reflectance at 0.531 µm + reflectance at 0.570 µm). With the availability of hyperspectral remote sensing that has the required narrow bands, and multispectral satellites such as MODIS with bands that are near to PRI, for instance band 11 (0.526–0.536 µm) and band 12 (0.546–0.556 µm), these bands have been used extensively in estimating ecosystem productivity, such as for broadleaf deciduous forest (Rahman et al., 2004), for broadleaf Mediterranean forest (Garbulsky et al., 2008), for boreal coniferous forest (Drolet et al., 2008) and for coniferous forest (Hilker et al., 2009). PRI has been proved to be well correlated with LUE in a wide range of biomes and it is suitable for vegetation that is planted homogeneously, single species as well as even-aged trees, in a regular pattern (Grace et al., 2007) such as in oil palm estates. Besides, PRI also includes the effect of environmental constraints such as water stress, temperature stress and nutrient stress. Thus, PRI could simplify the remote sensing based productivity models, as expressed by GPP = PRI × APAR (Garbulsky et al., 2011).

Extensive reviews have claimed that PRI is subjected primarily to atmospheric interference by clouds and aerosols as well as sun-target-sensor viewing angle (Garbulsky et al., 2011; Grace et al., 2007; Hilker et al., 2008b). Nevertheless, measurements of PRI can be improved through minimizing the atmospheric effects by radiative transfer models and by addressing the sun-target-sensor viewing angle by bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) methods, etc. (Garbulsky et al., 2011; Hilker et al., 2008a, 2008b, 2009).

sec.title: 3 Environmental constraints
sec.p: Environmental constraints are used to scale down the maximum LUE in the remote sensing based productivity models. For oil palm, productivity is sensitive to the variation of water availability which is commonly described by VPD and SWD (Henson, 2000; Lamade and Bouillet, 2005). As VPD increases when air humidity is reducing, it induces stoma closure to prevent water loss and gas exchange between oil palms and the atmosphere (Lamade and Bouillet, 2005). If the VPD is higher than 1.8 kPa it induces the stomata of oil palms to close (Dufrene and Saugier, 1993). Northern Peninsular Malaysia is struck by a dry season (i.e. December to March) and experiences approximately three months of minimum precipitation. During this time oil palms are greatly reliant on the supply of water in the ground (Henson and Harun, 2005; Henson et al., 2007). Studies showed that the stomata of oil palms tend to close when the soil water is reduced to about 67% of the usual soil water concentration (Dufrene et al., 1992; Lamade and Bouillet, 2005). Among the LUE models, only a few models (i.e. GLO-PEM, VPM, and C-Fix) include SWD. Several studies suggested that models such as the MOD17 should consider incorporating SWD as an environmental constraint (Coops et al., 2007; Kanniah et al., 2009; Yuan et al., 2007). Utilizing remote sensing based models that do not include SWD may overestimate the oil palm productivity in dry areas (Sharma, 2009). Therefore, including a soil water function in remote sensing based productivity models is crucial to estimate oil palm productivity during dry seasons.

None of the models reviewed incorporate nutrient availability (e.g. nitrogen content) as an environmental constraint. Insufficiency of nutrients like nitrogen limits oil palm growth because nutrients are needed for growth (Lamade and Bouillet, 2005). At present, as more onboard airborne (e.g. NASA’s Airborne Visible/Infrared Imaging Spectroradiometer AVIRIS) and spaceborne (e.g. EO1-Hyperion) hyperspectral sensors are available, canopy nitrogen content estimation is becoming possible (Waring et al., 2010). Canopy nitrogen content can be scaled up using EO1-Hyperion and AVIRIS data with accuracy within 0.25% and 0.19% N of leaf dry mass, respectively (Smith et al., 2003; Waring et al., 2010). However, the narrow hyperspectral bands are found to be highly influenced by atmospheric contamination (Smith et al., 2003). The recently launched WorldView-2 satellite has four new bands (i.e. coastal blue 0.4–0.45 µm, yellow 0.585–0.625 µm, red-edge 0.705–0.745 µm and NIR2 0.86–1.04 µm) which have been proved to be useful in vegetation analysis such as the detection of vegetation healthiness (Digital Globe, 2010). The yellow band could have the potential to detect the yellowish leaves of oil palms in which nutrients are insufficient (Agamuthu and Broughton, 1985). Furthermore, a recent study has also indicated that canopy nitrogen content is highly correlated with albedo (R
2 = 0.88) using the MODIS sensor (Ollinger et al., 2008; Waring et al., 2010). Therefore, we should now begin to consider nutrient availability in remote sensing based productivity models for estimating oil palm productivity.

Current remote sensing based productivity models have developed a variety of algorithms and assumptions in calculating respiration. CASA calculates NPP without estimating Ra while GLO-PEM, C-Fix, TURC and MOD17 calculate NPP by subtracting Ra from GPP. The LUE models VPM, EC-LUE, VI and TG were developed to estimate GPP rather than NPP. Recently, studies indicate that the MODIS Land Surface Temperature (LST) product could be used to infer respiration (Rahman et al., 2005; Sims et al., 2008). Since LST is relatively easy to obtain by remote sensing techniques compared with the existing algorithms and assumptions of respiration, it is suggested that more studies should use LST to quantify respiration.

sec.title: VII Conclusions and recommendations
sec.p: The accuracy of the remotely sensed based productivity models needs to be evaluated, in order to provide insights to further improve the models and thereby to quantify the oil palm ecosystem involvement in the global carbon cycle and its response to climate change. Several techniques such as biometric measurements, Eddy Covariance based flux tower observations, modelling and remote sensing based productivity models are available for examining the spatial and temporal variability in oil palm productivity, and the environmental drivers for this variation. Examining oil palm productivity at the local scale is practical using biometric measurements and Eddy Covariance based flux towers. They can also be used to calibrate, validate and improve the remote sensing based productivity models. Nevertheless, remote sensing based models are the most practical to quantify the oil palm productivity at regional and national scale. All the remote sensing based models which were discussed in section IV use vegetation indices to estimate fPAR empirically. By contrast, the algorithm based on radiation transfer theory utilized by the MOD17 to model the physical processes is more robust and suitable to estimate LAI/fPAR for different biome types over the globe.

Existing literature shows that oil palm productivity is largely affected by solar radiation (including diffuse solar radiation), vapour pressure deficit, soil moisture deficit and nutrient deficiency. It is clear that the existing remote sensing based models urgently need to be modified in terms of meteorological inputs, environmental constraints, and maximum LUE as a constant value, in order to estimate oil palm productivity accurately. Several research items are proposed, which integrate different approaches in order to achieve a complete understanding of the factors affecting oil palm productivity, and these are outlined below:

list-item.p: Separate the solar radiation into direct and diffuse radiation and incorporate the solar radiation as a scaling factor (0–1) to scale down the LUE measurement in tropical regions.
Utilize meteorological data from flux towers to significantly improve the estimation of oil palm productivity.
Use PRI instead of maximum LUE as a constant in remote sensing based productivity models for oil palm.
Soil moisture deficit as an environmental constraint should be included in remote sensing based productivity models.
Incorporate nutrient deficit as an environmental constraint in remote sensing based productivity models.
Use MODIS LST in the model to estimate oil palm respiration.

sec.p: Although CO2 fluxes cannot be observed directly at a larger scale, remote sensing has partly succeeded to infer the processes in the carbon cycle and impacts on climate change (Nemani et al., 2003; Zhao and Running, 2010). To improve our understanding of oil palm productivity as a whole, it is essential to upscale local observations to regional scales. Upscaling of oil palm productivity to regional scales can be carried out by using remotely sensed products such as LAI, fPAR and vegetation indices as inputs and represents the oil palm productivity in the form of pixels.

Oil palm estates in tropical regions such as Malaysia have provided adequate test sites for validating remote sensing based models, because of the large coverage areas of oil palm estates which are comparable with the pixel size (Cracknell, 2010). As a conclusion, it is urgently needed to examine the patterns (i.e. temporal and spatial variability) of oil palm productivity. Since oil palm cultivation has been expanding at a fast pace in the last few decades, it is crucial to conduct more research on oil palm productivity to understand its role in the global carbon cycle. Such studies are important to justify and address the effects of oil palm to future climate change.
